It's cleavage products, the beta-amyloid peptides are lipophilic metal chelators with metal-reducing activity. Bind transient metals such as copper, zinc and iron. In vitro, can reduce Cu2+ and Fe3+ to Cu+ and Fe2+, respectively. Beta-amyloid 42 is a more effective reductant than beta-amyloid 40. Beta-amyloid peptides bind to lipoproteins and apolipoproteins E and J in the CSF and to HDL particles in plasma, inhibiting metal-catalyzed oxidation of lipoproteins. Beta-APP42 may activate mononuclear phagocytes in the brain and elicit inflammatory responses. Promotes both tau aggregation and TPK II-mediated phosphorylation. Interaction with overexpressed HADH2 leads to oxidative stress and neurotoxicity. Also binds GPC1 in lipid rafts.
description: Ab40 and Ab42 are pathogenic amyloids implicated in Alzheimer’s disease.

experimental_techniques: Well-known human pathogenic amyloid implicated in Alzheimer disease that was studied by a multitude of techniques.
uniprot_description: Promotes microtubule assembly and stability, and might be involved in the establishment and maintenance of neuronal polarity. The C-terminus binds axonal microtubules while the N-terminus binds neural plasma membrane components, suggesting that tau functions as a linker protein between both. Axonal polarity is predetermined by TAU/MAPT localization (in the neuronal cell) in the domain of the cell body defined by the centrosome. The short isoforms allow plasticity of the cytoskeleton whereas the longer isoforms may preferentially play a role in its stabilization.
description: In Alzheimer disease, the neuronal cytoskeleton in the brain is progressively disrupted and replaced by tangles of paired helical filaments (PHF) and straight filaments, mainly composed of hyperphosphorylated forms of TAU (PHF-TAU or AD P-TAU). O-GlcNAcylation is greatly reduced in Alzheimer disease brain cerebral cortex leading to an increase in TAU/MAPT phosphorylations.

experimental_techniques: Well-known human pathogenic amyloid implicated in type 2 diabetes that was studied by a multitude of techniques.
uniprot_description: Selectively inhibits insulin-stimulated glucose utilization and glycogen deposition in muscle, while not affecting adipocyte glucose metabolism.
description: IAPP is the peptide subunit of amyloid found in pancreatic islets of type 2 diabetic patients and in insulinomas.

experimental_techniques: Well-known human pathogenic amyloid that was studied by a multitude of techniques.
uniprot_description: Calcium-regulated, actin-modulating protein that binds to the plus (or barbed) ends of actin monomers or filaments, preventing monomer exchange (end-blocking or capping). It can promote the assembly of monomers into filaments (nucleation) as well as sever filaments already formed. Plays a role in ciliogenesis.
description: The mutations D187N/Y convert its membrane type 1 matrix metalloprotease (MT1-MMP) cleavage products into pathogenic amyloids implicated in Finnish type amyloidosis. The N184K variant of the protein was identified as the etiological agent of a novel kidney-localized amyloidosis.

alternative_names: Non-A beta component of AD amyloid
experimental_techniques: Well-known human pathogenic amyloid implicated in Parkinson’s disease that was studied by a multitude of techniques.
uniprot_description: May be involved in the regulation of dopamine release and transport. Induces fibrillization of microtubule-associated protein tau. Reduces neuronal responsiveness to various apoptotic stimuli, leading to a decreased caspase-3 activation.
description: Pathogenic amyloid implicated in Parkinson’s disease.

experimental_techniques: Well-known human pathogenic amyloid implicated in familial visceral amyloidosis that was studied by a multitude of techniques.
uniprot_description: Lysozymes have primarily a bacteriolytic function; those in tissues and body fluids are associated with the monocyte-macrophage system and enhance the activity of immunoagents. Lysozyme C is capable of both hydrolysis and transglycosylation; it shows also a slight esterase activity. It acts rapidly on both peptide-substituted and unsubstituted peptidoglycan, and slowly on chitin oligosaccharides.
description: Mutations in lysozyme C can lead to pathogenic amyloidosis implicated in familial visceral amyloidosis.

experimental_techniques: Well-known human pathogenic amyloid implicated in haemodialysis-associated amyloidosis that was studied by a multitude of techniques.
uniprot_description: Component of the class I major histocompatibility complex (MHC). Involved in the presentation of peptide antigens to the immune system. Exogenously applied M.tuberculosis EsxA or EsxA-EsxB (or EsxA expressed in host) binds B2M and decreases its export to the cell surface (total protein levels do not change), probably leading to defects in class I antigen presentation.
description: It forms a pathogenic amyloid that is implicated in haemodialysis-associated amyloidosis.

experimental_techniques: definition of core by proteinase K resistance assay
description: Harpins are virulence factors in a plant pathogenic bacteria. Missense and deletion mutagenesis of HpaG indicated that the rate of HpaG fibril formation is modulated by a motif present in the C terminus. The plant cytotoxicity of HpaG is unique among the amyloid-forming proteins that occur in several microorganisms. Structural and morphological analogies between HpaG and disease-related amyloidogenic proteins, such as Abeta protein, suggest possible common biochemical characteristics in the induction of plant and animal cell death.

experimental_techniques: green birefringence of CR-stained protein aggregates
uniprot_description: Surface protein antigen implicated in dental caries.
description: Involved in amyloid and biofilm formation in the human dental plaque.

experimental_techniques: prion domain substitution Sup35 rescue assays
uniprot_description: Required in mushroom body gamma neurons for long-term memory in male courtship. Binds to mRNA 3'-UTRs. In its monomeric form, acts as a translational repressor of genes involved in neuronal growth, synapse formation and protein turnover. In its amyloid-like oligomeric form, acts as a translational activator. The monomeric form reduces poly(A) tail length and destabilizes mRNA while the oligomeric form protects and elongates the poly(A) tail and stabilizes mRNA.
description: Upon neuronal stimulation, forms stable amyloid-like oligomers composed of isoform A and isoform B which are required for formation of persistent long-term memory. Monomeric Orb2 keeps target mRNA in a translationally dormant state and experience-dependent conversion to the amyloidogenic state activates translation, resulting in persistent alteration of synaptic activity and stabilization of memory.

experimental_techniques: definition of core by proteinase K-digestion
uniprot_description: Prevents the cell division inhibition by proteins MinC and MinD at internal division sites while permitting inhibition at polar sites. This ensures cell division at the proper site by restricting the formation of a division septum at the midpoint of the long axis of the cell.
description: MinE of the Min system forms a ring-like structure that plays a critical role in triggering the oscillation cycle and thus facilitating placement of the division septum at the midcell. To form this ring, MinE self-assembles into amyloid fibril-like structures on the supported lipid bilayer.

uniprot_description: Cell surface adhesion protein which mediates both yeast-to-host tissue adherence and yeast aggregation. Plays an important role in the biofilm formation and pathogenesis of C.albicans infections. Necessary for C.albicans to bind to N-cadherin on endothelial cells and E-cadherin on oral epithelial cells and subsequent endocytosis by these cells. During disseminated infection, mediates initial trafficking to the brain and renal cortex and contributes to fungal persistence in the kidneys.
description: Aggregation by cell wall-bound Als adhesins of Candida albicans is amyloid-like, with self-propagating secondary-structure changes.

experimental_techniques: in vitro fibrillization assays with NES peptide
uniprot_description: Transcriptional regulator (lacking a basic DNA binding domain) which negatively regulates the basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) transcription factors by forming heterodimers and inhibiting their DNA binding and transcriptional activity. Implicated in regulating a variety of cellular processes, including cellular growth, senescence, differentiation, apoptosis, angiogenesis, and neoplastic transformation. Inhibits skeletal muscle and cardiac myocyte differentiation. Regulates the circadian clock by repressing the transcriptional activator activity of the CLOCK-ARNTL/BMAL1 heterodimer. Restricts the CLOCK and ARNTL/BMAL1 localization to the cytoplasm. Plays a role in both the input and output pathways of the circadian clock: in the input component, is involved in modulating the magnitude of photic entrainment and in the output component, contributes to the regulation of a variety of liver clock-controlled genes involved in lipid metabolism.
description: Whereas the isolated Id2 HLH motif is highly helical, large C-terminal Id2 fragments including the NES sequence are either unordered or aggregation-prone. The biological relevance of this is unknown.

uniprot_description: DNA and RNA-binding protein which regulates transcription and splicing. Involved in the regulation of CFTR splicing. It promotes CFTR exon 9 skipping by binding to the UG repeated motifs in the polymorphic region near the 3'-splice site of this exon. The resulting aberrant splicing is associated with pathological features typical of cystic fibrosis. May also be involved in microRNA biogenesis, apoptosis and cell division. Can repress HIV-1 transcription by binding to the HIV-1 long terminal repeat. Stabilizes the low molecular weight neurofilament (NFL) mRNA through a direct interaction with the 3' UTR.
description: TDP-43 is a major deposited protein in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and frontotemporal dementia with ubiquitin.

uniprot_description: Antimicrobial peptide which exerts its cytotoxic effects as a result of membrane disruption. Shows antibacterial activity against B.cereus, L.lactis, L.innocua, M.luteus, S.aureus, P.multoci, S.epidermidis and S.uberis.
description: The broad-spectrum amphibian AMP uperin-3.5, which has a random-coil structure in solution but adopts an alpha-helical structure in membrane-like environments, forms amyloid fibrils rapidly in solution at neutral pH. These fibrils are cytotoxic to model neuronal cells.

uniprot_description: Microbicidal activity. Active against E.coli, Listeria monocytogenes and C.albicans, in vitro.
description: The antimicrobial PG-1 induces strong cytotoxic activities on cell membrane by its channel-forming ability.

uniprot_description: E protein plays a central role in virus morphogenesis and assembly. Acts as a viroporin and self-assembles in host membranes forming pentameric protein-lipid pores that allow ion transport. Activates the host NLRP3 inflammasome, leading to IL-1beta overproduction. Forms cation-selective ion channels.
description: The amyloidogenic nature of the TK9 fragment might be important for channel formation.

experimental_techniques: in vitro amyloid fibril formation of peptide
uniprot_description: Atrial natriuretic factor is a hormone playing a key role in cardiovascular homeostasis through regulation of natriuresis, diuresis, and vasodilation. Also plays a role in female pregnancy by promoting trophoblast invasion and spiral artery remodeling in uterus.
description: The pathogenic amyloid is formed by the propeptide of the hormone and is implicated in senile amyloid of atria of heart.

experimental_techniques: identified in atrial amyloid fibrils extracted from patients
in vitro fibrillization assays with ANP
uniprot_description: Atrial natriuretic factor is a hormone playing a key role in cardiovascular homeostasis through regulation of natriuresis, diuresis, and vasodilation. Also plays a role in female pregnancy by promoting trophoblast invasion and spiral artery remodeling in uterus.
description: ANP is the major low molecular weight protein in atrial amyloid of Isolated Atrial Amyloidosis (IAA) and Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) patients. Plasma factors and lipoproteins have an important role in controlling ANP aggregation.

experimental_techniques: in vitro amyloid fibril formation assays with Pum prion domain (NQ1)
Pum NQ1 can generate the Pin+ trait in yeast
uniprot_description: Sequence-specific RNA-binding protein that acts as a post-transcriptional repressor by binding the 3'-UTR of mRNA targets. Binds to an RNA consensus sequence, the Pumilio Response Element (PRE), 5'-UGUANAUA-3', that is related to the Nanos Response Element (NRE). Mediates post-transcriptional repression of transcripts via different mechanisms: acts via direct recruitment of deadenylase complexes leading to translational inhibition and mRNA degradation.
description: The functional benefits of the prion form are not known precisely. However, expression of the prion domain (NQ1) negatively regulates endogenous Pum, producing gene dosage-dependent pum loss-of-function NMJ phenotypes. NQ1 coexpression also suppresses lethality and NMJ phenotypes caused by overexpression of Pum in muscles. The Q/N block of NQ1 is required for these phenotypic effects.

experimental_techniques: peptides assayed for nucleation of fibril formation of full-length SOD1: C-Terminal segment 147GVIGIAQ153 seeds aggregation of wt SOD1
crystal structures of the two fibril-forming segments 101-DSVISLS-107 and 147-GVIGIAQ-153 show steric zipper structures
MD and REMD simulations of the GVIGIAQ peptide
uniprot_description: Superoxide dismutase destroys radicals which are normally produced within the cells and which are toxic to biological systems.
description: Human Sod1 can form a pathogenic amyloid implicated in familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, a progressive neurodegenerative disease.

experimental_techniques: identified in senile plaques of AD brain
vitronectin immunoreactivity overlaps with the amyloid fibril-specific OC antibody
membrane permeabilization assays with synthetic vesicles
uniprot_description: Vitronectin is a cell adhesion and spreading factor found in serum and tissues. Vitronectin interact with glycosaminoglycans and proteoglycans. Is recognized by certain members of the integrin family and serves as a cell-to-substrate adhesion molecule. Inhibitor of the membrane-damaging effect of the terminal cytolytic complement pathway.
description: Vitronectin is present within the deposits associated with Alzheimer disease (AD), age-related macular degeneration (AMD), atherosclerosis, systemic amyloidoses, and glomerulonephritis. The role of vitronectin in the pathophysiology of these diseases is currently unknown.

uniprot_description: Forms fibre spikes that protrude from each vertex of the icosahedral capsid. Interacts with host coxsackievirus and adenovirus receptor CXADR located at the cell tight junctions to provide virion initial attachment to target cell. The fiber protein binds to CXADR with a higher affinity than CXADR binds to itself, thereby blocking the cell-cell adhesion function of CXADR dimers and leading to local disruption of the tight junction. Fiber protein present on neo-synthesized particles may thus disrupt the junctional integrity in order to facilitate further neighboring cells infection. Fiber proteins are shed during virus entry, when virus is still at the cell surface.
description: The peptide corresponding to the portion of the shaft immediately adjacent to the head (residues 355-396) has been synthesized chemically. The peptide failed to assemble correctly and instead formed amyloid-type fibrils. The minimum fibril-forming sequence is 387'GAITIG'392.

experimental_techniques: in vitro fibrillization assays of synthetic peptide
uniprot_description: Provides resistance to osmotic stress. May be important for stationary-phase survival.
description: The sequence of the Escherichia coli OsmB protein was found to resemble that of the C-terminal region of the beta amyloid protein of Alzheimer's disease. The peptide OsmB(28-44) forms amyloid fibrils, however the associated functional relevance is not known.

experimental_techniques: Assaying the effects of C-terminal truncations and mutations of the amyloidogenic peptide on amyloid formation
immunofluorescence assays using anti-VP4 monoclonal antibody and confocal microscopy
uniprot_description:: Protease VP4 is a serine protease that cleaves the polyprotein into its final products.
description: VP4 forms unusual intracellular tubule-like structures during viral infection that deform the host cytoskeleton and nucleus, which is potentially associated with IBDV lytic infection. The assembly of VP4 reduces the cytotoxicity of protease activity in host cells which might prevent the premature cell death and facilitate viral replication.

experimental_techniques: in vitro fibrillization assays of synthetic peptide
uniprot_description: Biofilm-associated surface protein.
description: It plays a role in bacterial biofilm formation.

experimental_techniques: in vitro fibrillization assays of wt and peptides
uniprot_description: Secreted glycoprotein regulating the activation of different signaling pathways in adjacent cells to control different processes including cell adhesion, cell-matrix adhesion, cytoskeleton organization and cell migration. Promotes substrate adhesion, spreading and formation of focal contacts.
description: The pathogenic amyloid formed by the olfactomedin domain of myocilin is implicated in glaucoma.

uniprot_description: Prostatic acidic phosphatase is a non-specific tyrosine phosphatase that dephosphorylates a diverse number of substrates under acidic conditions (pH 4-6) including alkyl, aryl, and acyl orthophosphate monoesters and phosphorylated proteins. Has lipid phosphatase activity and inactivates lysophosphatidic acid in seminal plasma.
description: PAPf39, a 39-residue peptide fragment PAP(248-286) from human prostatic acidic phosphatase forms amyloid fibrils in semen (SEVI), which increase HIV infectivity by up to 5 orders of magnitude.

Dermaseptin S9 (Drs S9) is an atypical cationic frog antimicrobial peptide with a long hydrophobic core and with a propensity to form amyloid-like fibrils. It is a potent antibacterial, acting on both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.

experimental_techniques: in vitro fibrillation assay with amyloidogenic fragment
aggregation seeding assay with peptide in vitro and in vivo
uniprot_description: Acts as a tumor suppressor in many tumor types; induces growth arrest or apoptosis depending on the physiological circumstances and cell type. Involved in cell cycle regulation as a trans-activator that acts to negatively regulate cell division by controlling a set of genes required for this process.
description: p53 aggregation can lead to loss-of-function (LoF), dominant-negative (DN) and gain-of-function (GoF) effects, with adverse cancer consequences.

experimental_techniques: in vitro fibrillation assay with amyloidogenic fragment
uniprot_description: Non-inhibitory serpin. Ovalbumin (OVA) is a major globular storage protein in egg white.
description: OVA forms semiflexible fibrillar aggregates during heat-induced gelation.

experimental_techniques: well-known human pathogenic amyloid implicated in lattice corneal dystrophy that was studied by multiple techniques
uniprot_description: TGFBIp plays a role in cell adhesion. May play a role in cell-collagen interactions.
description: TGFBIp amyloid formation is implicated in lattice corneal dystrophy (LCD), which manifests as amyloid-type aggregates in the corneal stroma.

experimental_techniques: aggregation enhanced with an increase in peptide concentration
uniprot_description: Contributes to the transparency and refractive index of the lens. Has chaperone-like activity, preventing aggregation of various proteins under a wide range of stress conditions.
description: An αA-crystallin-derived peptide, αA66-80 (1.8 kDa), is a prominent LMW peptide concentrated in water-insoluble fractions of the aging lens. The peptide has amyloid-like properties, forms amyloid fibrils in vitro and preferentially insolubilizes α-crystallin from lens-soluble fractions causing age-related cataract formation.

experimental_techniques: well-known human pathogenic amyloid studied by multiple techniques
uniprot_description: Crystallins are the dominant structural components of the vertebrate eye lens.
description: Human γD-crystallin aggregates into amyloid fibrils under acidic conditions, which makes it a major component of cataracts.

experimental_techniques: in vitro fibrillation assay with amyloidogenic fragment
uniprot_description: Lysozymes have primarily a bacteriolytic function; those in tissues and body fluids are associated with the monocyte-macrophage system and enhance the activity of immunoagents.
description: Some of the lysozyme mutants in humans cause systemic amyloidosis. Hen egg white lysozyme (HEWL) is known to form amyloid fibrils under denaturing conditions in organic solvent, detergent, chemical denaturant or acid pH with high temperature. HEWL has been well studied as a model protein of amyloid fibrils formation.

Merozoite surface protein 2 (MSP2), an abundant glycosylphosphatidylinositol-anchored protein on the surface of Plasmodium falciparum merozoites that forms amyloid-like fibrils in solution under physiological conditions. It may be a component of the fibrillar surface coat on P. falciparum merozoites. The N-terminal helix has an important role in both membrane interactions and amyloid formation.

uniprot_description: This protein is involved in the gluconeogenesis pathway, which is part of Carbohydrate biosynthesis.
description: Four fibrillogenic regions were predicted in human TPI corresponding to the beta3, beta6, beta7 y alpha8 of the TIM barrel. From these, the beta3-strand region (residues 59-66) proved to be highly fibrillogenic. Despite the fibrillogenic regions present in TPI, the enzyme maintained under native-favoring conditions displayed low fibrillogenic propensity. This amyloid-resistance can be attributed to the three-dimensional arrangement of the protein, where β-strands, susceptible to aggregation, are protected in the core of the molecule. Destabilization of the protein structure may expose inner regions promoting β-aggregation, as well as the formation of hydrophobic disordered aggregates.

experimental_techniques: amyloid core defined by quenched hydrogen exchange NMR
uniprot_description: Cystatin-B is an intracellular thiol proteinase inhibitor. Tightly binding reversible inhibitor of cathepsins L, H and B.
description: Members of the cystatin superfamily are involved in an inherited form of cerebral amyloid angiopathy and readily form amyloid fibrils in vitro. Stefin B was shown to interact with amyloid-beta peptide of Alzheimer's disease in an oligomer specific manner, both in vitro and in the cells. It also has been shown that endogenous stefin B (with E at site 31) but especially the EPM1 mutant R68X and Y31-stefin B variant, and to a lesser extent EPM1 mutant G4R, are prone to form aggregates in cells.

experimental_techniques: in vitro amyloid formation of peptide
uniprot_description: Terminates signal transduction at the neuromuscular junction by rapid hydrolysis of the acetylcholine released into the synaptic cleft. Role in neuronal apoptosis.
description: AChE normally resides mainly on cholinergic neuronal membranes, but is abnormally localized to senile plaques in Alzheimer's disease. AChE and A beta interact in vitro; the fibrillogenic region within AChE may be relevant to the interaction of AChE with amyloid fibrils formed by Abeta.

experimental_techniques: sequence analysis identified C-termini of human tubulin subunits alpha and beta from isolated amyloid fibrils of patients of familial amyloidosis, British type
in vitro amyloid formation of peptides
uniprot_description: Tubulin is the major constituent of microtubules. It binds two moles of GTP, one at an exchangeable site on the beta chain and one at a non-exchangeable site on the alpha chain.
description: The C-terminal fragments of both alpha- and beta-tubulin are closely associated to the amyloid deposits of familial amyloidosis, British type.

uniprot_description: Cro represses genes normally expressed in early phage development and is necessary for the late stage of lytic growth. It does this by binding to the OL and OR operators regions normally used by the repressor protein for lysogenic maintenance.
description: The peptide corresponding to the 434 Cro helix 4 has low water solubility and the mutated form forms amyloid fibres in isolation.

uniprot_description: Required for the function of light chain amino-acid transporters. Involved in sodium-independent, high-affinity transport of large neutral amino acids such as phenylalanine, tyrosine, leucine, arginine and tryptophan. Involved in guiding and targeting of LAT1 and LAT2 to the plasma membrane. When associated with SLC7A6 or SLC7A7 acts as an arginine/glutamine exchanger, following an antiport mechanism for amino acid transport, influencing arginine release in exchange for extracellular amino acids. Plays a role in nitric oxide synthesis in human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) via transport of L-arginine. Required for normal and neoplastic cell growth. When associated with SLC7A5/LAT1, is also involved in the transport of L-DOPA across the blood-brain barrier, and that of thyroid hormones triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4) across the cell membrane in tissues such as placenta. Involved in the uptake of methylmercury (MeHg) when administered as the L-cysteine or D,L-homocysteine complexes, and hence plays a role in metal ion homeostasis and toxicity. When associated with SLC7A5 or SLC7A8, involved in the cellular activity of small molecular weight nitrosothiols, via the stereoselective transport of L-nitrosocysteine (L-CNSO) across the transmembrane. Together with ICAM1, regulates the transport activity LAT2 in polarized intestinal cells, by generating and delivering intracellular signals. When associated with SLC7A5, plays an important role in transporting L-leucine from the circulating blood to the retina across the inner blood-retinal barrier.
description: Amyloidogenic region information is taken from dedicated databases for amyloidogenic peptides. Biological relevance not known.

uniprot_description: RNA-binding protein that binds to misfolded non-coding RNAs, pre-5S rRNA, and several small cytoplasmic RNA molecules known as Y RNAs. May stabilize some of these RNAs and protect them from degradation. May play roles in cilia formation and/or maintenance.
description: Region information taken from dedicated databases for amyloidogenic peptides. Biological relevance not known.

experimental_techniques: MS identification of ABri from isolated amyloid fibrils of Familial British dementia (FBD) patients
amyloid-specific antibodies as well as ABri-specific antibodies recognize parenchymal and vascular lesions in FBD patients
uniprot_description: ITM2B-derived peptides play a regulatory role in the processing of the beta-amyloid A4 precursor protein (APP) and acts as an inhibitor of the beta-amyloid peptide aggregation and fibrils deposition. Plays a role in the induction of neurite outgrowth. Functions as a protease inhibitor by blocking access of secretases to APP cleavage sites. Mature BRI2 (mBRI2) functions as a modulator of the beta-amyloid A4 precursor protein (APP) processing leading to a strong reduction in the secretion of secretase-processed beta-amyloid protein 40 and beta-amyloid protein 42. Bri23 peptide prevents aggregation of APP beta-amyloid protein 42 peptide into toxic oligomers. A single base substitution at the stop codon of ITM2B generates a 277-residue precursor that is cleaved at the normal furin processing site to generate the ABri amyloidogenic peptide. ABri accumulates in the brain and produces amyloid fibrils responsible for neuronal dysfunction and dementia. ABri peptide variant forms fibrils in vitro.
description: Pathogenic amyloid-forming peptide stemming from a stop codon mutation of ITM2B that is implicated in British-type cerebral amyloid angiopathy.

experimental_techniques: MS analysis of isolated leptomeningeal amyloid fibrils from familial Danish dementia patients
uniprot_description: ITM2B-derived peptides play a regulatory role in the processing of the beta-amyloid A4 precursor protein (APP) and acts as an inhibitor of the beta-amyloid peptide aggregation and fibrils deposition. Plays a role in the induction of neurite outgrowth. Functions as a protease inhibitor by blocking access of secretases to APP cleavage sites. Mature BRI2 (mBRI2) functions as a modulator of the beta-amyloid A4 precursor protein (APP) processing leading to a strong reduction in the secretion of secretase-processed beta-amyloid protein 40 and beta-amyloid protein 42. Bri23 peptide prevents aggregation of APP beta-amyloid protein 42 peptide into toxic oligomers. ADan is generated by cleavage of the mutated precursor at the normal furin processing site. ADan accumulates in the brain and produces amyloid fibrils responsible for neuronal dysfunction and dementia.
description: ADan is a pathogenic amyloid-forming peptide stemming from a stop codon mutation that is implicated in Danish-type cerebral amyloid angiopathy.

experimental_techniques: anti-proliferative activity against 2 human glioma cell lines
uniprot_description: Cn-AMP2 has antimicrobial activity against Gram-positive bacteria B.subtilis (MIC=150 microg/ml) and S.aureus (MIC=170 microg/ml), and against Gram-negative bacteria E.coli (MIC=170 microg/ml) and P.aeruginosa (MIC=169 microg/ml).
description: Cn-AMP2 is an antimicrobial peptide derived from liquid endosperm of coconut.

experimental_techniques: pH-dependent fibrillization assays with amyloidogenic fragments
uniprot_description: Glucanases possibly play a role in cell expansion during growth, in cell-cell fusion during mating, and in spore release during sporulation. This enzyme may be involved in beta-glucan degradation and also function biosynthetically as a transglycosylase.
description: Bgl2p forms fibrils, a process that is enforced in the presence of other cell wall components.

experimental_techniques: STOP-loss in families affected by axonal neuropathy
uniprot_description: Neurofilaments usually contain three intermediate filament proteins: L, M, and H which are involved in the maintenance of neuronal caliber. NF-H has an important function in mature axons that is not subserved by the two smaller NF proteins.
description: A frameshift-inducing mutation of Pro1014 in NF-H leads to translation of the 3'UTR resulting in an amyloidogenic protein extension.

experimental_techniques: negative stain EM of immunogold labeled samples from pellicles
description: Participates in bacterial biofilm formation. Its amyloid fibre formation is nucleated by TapA.

uniprot_description: Acts as a transcriptional regulator. Promotes transcription repression. Promotes transcription activation in differentiated myotubes. Binds to double- and single-stranded DNA sequences. Binds to the transcription suppressor CATR sequence of the COX5B promoter. Binds with high affinity to RNA molecules that contain AU-rich elements (AREs) found within the 3'-UTR of many proto-oncogenes and cytokine mRNAs. Binds both to nuclear and cytoplasmic poly(A) mRNAs. Binds to poly(G) and poly(A), but not to poly(U) or poly(C) RNA homopolymers. Binds to the 5'-ACUAGC-3' RNA consensus sequence.
description: HNRPDL is linked to the development of limb-girdle muscular dystrophy 1G. HNRPDL inclusion bodies display characteristic amyloid hallmarks and are highly neurotoxic.

experimental_techniques: comparative crystal structure analysis in different pH conditions
description: Miraculin-like proteins, belonging to the Kunitz superfamily, are natural plant defense agents against pests and predators. Murraya koenigii miraculin-like protein (MKMLP) gradually precipitates below pH 7.5 and forms amyloid fibres.

experimental_techniques: laser microdissection and MS/MS analysis of the amyloid deposits of hepatic amyloidosis patients
uniprot_description: Has a neutrophil chemotactic activity. Also a positive regulator of chondrocyte proliferation. Despite its fold it does not show metalloendopeptidase activity.
description: Leukocyte cell-derived chemotaxin 2 (LECT2) amyloidosis (ALect2) is a common cause of hepatic amyloidosis in the USA. Pathogenic mutations were not discovered, suggesting that constitutive or compensatory LECT2 overexpression led to ALect2 deposition.

DewA is a highly surface-active class I fungal hydrophobin that spontaneously self-assembles into amphipathic monolayers at hydrophobic:hydrophilic interfaces. These monolayers are composed of fibrils that are a form of functional amyloid. Predicted region of amyloid fibre formation: 68-81.

experimental_techniques: proteome-wide bioinformatics survey for prionogenic proteins combined with experimental validation
uniprot_description: Positive regulator of sporulation-specific genes and of sporulation. Required for premeiotic DNA synthesis and meiotic chromosomal segregation. May act in a nutritional signaling pathway.
description: Rim4 forms amyloid-like aggregates and it is the amyloid-like form of Rim4 that is the active, translationally repressive form of the protein. Rim4 aggregation is a developmentally regulated process. Starvation induces the conversion of monomeric Rim4 into amyloid-like aggregates, thereby activating the protein to bring about repression of translation.

experimental_techniques: MS/MS analysis of SDS-insoluble purified amyloid fibrils
description: Bacterial biofilm formation. FapC is the main fibril monomer, whose fibril formation is probably nucleated by FapB.

experimental_techniques: MS/MS analysis of SDS-insoluble purified amyloid fibrils
description: Bacterial biofilm formation. FapB is an amyloid-forming protein, probably a nucleator for FapC polymerization.

experimental_techniques: in vitro amyloid formation of recombinant MspA
MS/MS analysis of depolymerized purified cell wall sheets
description: Bacterial biofilm formation. Major constituent of the extracellular cell wall sheaths encasing the methanogenic archaea Methanosaeta thermophila PT.

uniprot_description: S100A8 is a calcium- and zinc-binding protein which plays a prominent role in the regulation of inflammatory processes and immune response. It can induce neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion. Predominantly found as calprotectin (S100A8/A9) which has a wide plethora of intra- and extracellular functions.
description: S100A8/A9 forms amyloids in the ageing prostate. Infection, inflammation and amyloid self-assembly of S100A8/A9 proteins in the presence of calcium or/and zinc are important factors leading to CA depositions in the prostate gland.

uniprot_description: S100A9 is a calcium- and zinc-binding protein which plays a prominent role in the regulation of inflammatory processes and immune response. It can induce neutrophil chemotaxis, adhesion, can increase the bactericidal activity of neutrophils by promoting phagocytosis via activation of SYK, PI3K/AKT, and ERK1/2 and can induce degranulation of neutrophils by a MAPK-dependent mechanism. Predominantly found as calprotectin (S100A8/A9) which has a wide plethora of intra- and extracellular functions.
description: S100A8/A9 forms amyloids in the ageing prostate. Infection, inflammation and amyloid self-assembly of S100A8/A9 proteins in the presence of calcium or/and zinc are important factors leading to CA depositions in the prostate gland.

uniprot_description: Defensin-6 has very low antimicrobial activity against Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria. May protect cells against infection with HIV-1.
description: Defensin-6 is an antimicrobial peptide which undergoes an ordered self-assembly of microbe-entangling peptide nanonets. It can agglutinate both Gram-negative and -positive bacteria, and block the invasion of mammalian mucosal cells by the human gastrointestinal pathogens, Listeria monocytogenes, Salmonella typhimurium and Yersinia enterocolitica.

uniprot_description: PB1-F2 plays an important role in promoting lung pathology in both primary viral infection and secondary bacterial infection. Promotes alteration of mitochondrial morphology, dissipation of mitochondrial membrane potential, and cell death. Alternatively, inhibits the production of interferon in the infected cell at the level of host mitochondrial antiviral signaling MAVS. Its level of expression differs greatly depending on which cell type is infected, in a manner that is independent of the levels of expression of other viral proteins. Monocytic cells are more affected than epithelial cells. Seems to disable virus-infected monocytes or other host innate immune cells. During early stage of infection, predisposes the mitochondria to permeability transition through interaction with host SLC25A6/ANT3 and VDAC1. These proteins participate in the formation of the permeability transition pore complex (PTPC) responsible of the release of mitochondrial products that triggers apoptosis.
description: The membrane-lytic activity of PB1-F2 is closely related to its amyloid-like supramolecular organization. The C-terminal domain of the protein was found to be responsible for amyloid formation.

experimental_techniques: in vitro polymerization assays with ThT fluorescence
description: Amyloid fiber anchoring/assembly protein TapA implicated in bacterial biofilm formation by TasA. The TapA variant with the amyloidogenic region being deleted acts as a dominant negative in TasA amyloid fibre formation.

experimental_techniques: amyloid fibrils of the mutated ApoAII variant were isolated from patient samples
uniprot_description: Apolipoprotein A-II may stabilize HDL (high density lipoprotein) structure by its association with lipids, and affect the HDL metabolism.
description: Mutation of the STOP codon leads to translation of the 3'UTR resulting in an amyloidogenic protein extension causing hereditary renal amyloidosis.

uniprot_description: Water-repellent structural protein required for surface hydrophobicity and formation of aerial hyphae during filamentous growth.
description: Rep1-1 is a representative of fungal proteins that form functional amyloid-like filaments at the hyphal surface. This peptide reduced the water surface tension to as low as 36 mJ m(-2). Rep1-1 filaments decrease in length at increasing concentrations.

uniprot_description: Beta-endorphin: Endogenous orexigenic opiate.
description: Beta-endorphin is an endogenous opiate peptide hormone that is stored in the form of amyloid in dense-core vesicles. Ion-specific effects largely influence the dynamics of its amyloid formation.

experimental_techniques: identified in patient samples as SDS-insoluble fibrillar material
uniprot_description: Pulmonary surfactant associated proteins promote alveolar stability by lowering the surface tension at the air-liquid interface in the peripheral air spaces. Pulmonary surfactant consists of 90% lipid and 10% protein. There are 4 surfactant-associated proteins: 2 collagenous, carbohydrate-binding glycoproteins (SP-A and SP-D) and 2 small hydrophobic proteins (SP-B and SP-C).
description: The amyloid form of pulmonary surfactant-associated protein C is implicated in human lung disease, namely in pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. Interestingly, the C-terminal domain of proSP-C, CTC-Brichos works as a chaperone that binds unfolded (pro)SP-C and thereby prevents it from aggregation. Mutations associated with human lung fibrosis are to a large extent localized to this chaperone domain and cause SP-C misfolding and aggregation by inactivating Brichos chaperon function, thus acting in an indirect manner.

uniprot_description: Prostatic acid phosphatase is a non-specific tyrosine phosphatase that dephosphorylates a diverse number of substrates under acidic conditions (pH 4-6) including alkyl, aryl, and acyl orthophosphate monoesters and phosphorylated proteins. Has lipid phosphatase activity and inactivates lysophosphatidic acid in seminal plasma.
description: PAP(85-120) from human prostatic acidic phosphatase forms positively charged fibrillar structures in semen that increase virion attachment to cells.

experimental_techniques: in vitro amyloid fibril formation of peptide
uniprot_description: Cardiac hormone which may function as a paracrine antifibrotic factor in the heart. Also plays a key role in cardiovascular homeostasis through natriuresis, diuresis, vasorelaxation, and inhibition of renin and aldosterone secretion.
description: The propeptide of the BNP hormone is also implicated in senile amyloid of atria of heart.

experimental_techniques: identified in atrial amyloid fibrils extracted from patients
uniprot_description: Cardiac hormone which may function as a paracrine antifibrotic factor in the heart. Also plays a key role in cardiovascular homeostasis through natriuresis, diuresis, vasorelaxation, and inhibition of renin and aldosterone secretion.
description: ANP, BNP and their precursor peptides NT-proANP and NT-proBNP are constituents of amyloid fibrils of isolated atrial amyloidosis (IAA), with ANP being the main constituent.

experimental_techniques: in vitro amyloid fibril formation of peptides
description: Streptomyces bacteria form reproductive aerial hyphae that are covered with a pattern of pairwise aligned fibrils called rodlets. The presence of the rodlet layer requires two homologous rodlin proteins, RdlA and RdlB, and the functional amyloid chaplin proteins, ChpA-H. RdlB, but not RdlA, readily assembles into amyloid fibrils.

uniprot_description: Plays a role in sequence-specific regulation of nuclear pre-mRNA abundance.
description: Nrd1 is an essential protein that possesses an RRM and is important for termination of small non-coding RNAs. Nrd1 and Nab3 dimerize to bind RNA sequence elements through their RNA recognition motifs (RRMs). RNA binding protein with a low complexity, prion domain formimg a dynamic subcellular matrix in which RNA metabolism takes place. The biological signals that induce and dissolve these structures remain to be identified. One good candidate, however, is phosphorylation of Nab3 and Nrd1 both of which have been shown to be phospho-proteins. Interestingly, dephosphorylation during glucose starvation is concurrent with rearrangement of Nrd1 into nuclear punctae. This process could be related to the assembly potential of Nab3 and Nrd1 observed here.

experimental_techniques: Congo red binding, absorbance and birefringence
showing colocalization of GH and Zn(II) in pituitary tissue by immunohistochemistry
uniprot_description: Plays an important role in growth control. Its major role in stimulating body growth is to stimulate the liver and other tissues to secrete IGF-1. It stimulates both the differentiation and proliferation of myoblasts. It also stimulates amino acid uptake and protein synthesis in muscle and other tissues.
description: GH is a hormone that is stored in the form of functional amyloid in pituitary secretory granules. Fibrillization occurs in the presence of metal ions, especially zinc. Residues 72-82 were predicted with maximum aggregation tendency by TANGO.

experimental_techniques: coaggregation and seeding assays with Ab40
uniprot_description: Tachykinins are active peptides which excite neurons, evoke behavioral responses, are potent vasodilators and secretagogues, and contract (directly or indirectly) many smooth muscles.
description: Physalaemin is expressed by the skin glands of a frog. It contains modified residues: the first residue is pyrrolidone carboxylic acid the last is methionine amide. The peptide formed amyloid-like fibrils in vitro in the presence of heparin, and these amyloids were found to be nontoxic in neuronal cells. The peptide co-aggregates with Ab40.

experimental_techniques: coaggregation and seeding assays with Ab40
uniprot_description: Tachykinins are active peptides which excite neurons, evoke behavioral responses, are potent vasodilators and secretagogues, and contract (directly or indirectly) many smooth muscles.
description: Kassinin is expressed by the skin glands of a frog. It contains methionine amide in the last position. The peptide formed amyloid-like fibrils in vitro in the presence of heparin, and these amyloids were found to be nontoxic in neuronal cells. The peptide co-aggregates with Ab40.

experimental_techniques: coaggregation and seeding assays with Ab40
uniprot_description: Tachykinins are active peptides which excite neurons, evoke behavioral responses, are potent vasodilators and secretagogues, and contract (directly or indirectly) many smooth muscles.
description: Substance P contains methionine amide in the last position. The peptide formed amyloid-like fibrils in vitro in the presence of heparin, and these amyloids were found to be nontoxic in neuronal cells. The peptide co-aggregates with Ab40.

experimental_techniques: MS/MS identification of protein in amyloids extracted from localized cutaneous amyloidosis (LCA) patients
in vitro fibrillation assay with peptides
uniprot_description: Could be involved in cell-cell and/or cell-matrix interactions necessary for normal growth control. Pro-apoptotic protein that functions intracellularly upstream of JNK activation and cytochrome c release.
description: Galectin-7 was identified as one of the precursor proteins of of primary and secondary localized cutaneous amyloidosis (LCA) associated with Bowen's disease. Degraded fragments of the galectin-7 molecule produced by limited trypsin digestion, formed amyloid fibrils after incubation at pH 2.0. These results suggest that the tryptic peptides of galectin-7 released at neutral pH, may lead to amyloid fibril formation of PLCA in the intracellular acidified conditions during keratinocyte apoptosis via regulation by the galectin-7 peptide as well as actin and cytokeratins.

experimental_techniques: MS/MS identification of peptide from the localized amyloid deposits of patients treated by subcutaneously administered enfuvirtide
description: Enfuvirtide is a 36 amino acids synthetic peptide works by disrupting the HIV-1 molecular machinery at the final stage of fusion with the target cell, preventing uninfected cells from becoming infected. A biomimetic peptide, enfuvirtide was designed to mimic components of the HIV-1 fusion machinery and displace them, preventing normal fusion. Drugs that disrupt fusion of virus and target cell are termed entry inhibitors or fusion inhibitors. Protein and peptide drugs administered subcutaneously, such as insulin and enfuvirtide can be amyloidogenic and result in localized amyloid deposits at the sites of medication injections.

experimental_techniques: in vitro ThT fluorescence assays with GS domain
uniprot_description: Corneodesmosin (CDSN) is a 529-aa glycoprotein exclusively found in the cornified squamous epithelia and involved in the cohesion of the upper epidermis. CDSN is synthesized by the differentiated keratinocytes in the uppermost epidermal layers, namely the upper spinous and granular layers. On secretion, it localizes in the extracellular core of desmosomes. Important for the epidermal barrier integrity.
description: Heterozygous nonsense mutations in the CDSN gene encoding corneodesmosin (CDSN) (the Q215X, Q200X, and Y239X mutations were identified so far where X stands for stop codons) cause hypotrichosis simplex of the scalp (HSS), a nonsyndromic form of alopecia. Truncated mutants of CDSN (mutCDSN), which bear the N-terminal adhesive Gly/Ser-rich domain (GS domain) of the protein, abnormally accumulate as amorphous deposits at the periphery of hair follicles and in the papillary dermis of the patient skin. The mutCDSN deposits display an affinity for amyloidophilic dyes. Recombinant forms of mutCDSN and of the GS domain assemble in vitro into ring-shaped oligomeric structures and fibrils.

experimental_techniques: lipid binding and LPL activity assays
uniprot_description: Component of triglyceride-rich very low density lipoproteins (VLDL) and high density lipoproteins (HDL) in plasma. Plays a multifaceted role in triglyceride homeostasis. Intracellularly, promotes hepatic very low density lipoprotein 1 (VLDL1) assembly and secretion; extracellularly, attenuates hydrolysis and clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins. Impairs the lipolysis of TRLs by inhibiting lipoprotein lipase and the hepatic uptake of TRLs by remnant receptors. Formed of several curved helices connected via semiflexible hinges, so that it can wrap tightly around the curved micelle surface and easily adapt to the different diameters of its natural binding partners.
description: A form of amyloidosis that is characterized by renal insufficiency is caused by a new apolipoprotein C-III variant, D25V. Despite their uremic state, the D25V-carriers exhibit low triglyceride (TG) and apolipoprotein C-III levels, and low very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL)/high high-density lipoprotein (HDL) profile. Amyloid fibrils comprise the D25V-variant only, showing that wild-type apolipoprotein C-III does not contribute to amyloid deposition in vivo. The mutation profoundly impacts helical structure stability of D25V-variant, which is remarkably fibrillogenic under physiological conditions. D25V apolipoprotein C-III is a new human amyloidogenic protein and the first conferring cardioprotection even in the unfavourable context of renal failure, extending the evidence for an important cardiovascular protective role of apolipoprotein C-III deficiency.

experimental_techniques: Laser microdissection followed by MS/MS identification of the protein from the amyloid deposits of patients
uniprot_description: May have a role in chylomicrons and VLDL secretion and catabolism. Required for efficient activation of lipoprotein lipase by ApoC-II; potent activator of LCAT. Apoa-IV is a major component of HDL and chylomicrons.
description: Renal AApoAIV amyloidosis typically presents with progressive chronic kidney disease and histologically exhibits extensive medullary involvement with sparing of the cortex. Also identified in the amyloids of some patients with systemic amyloidosis. Common polymorphisms might play a role in AApoAIV amyloidosis as a variant with three frequent sequence variations was detected in the deposits of a medullary amyloidosis patient.

uniprot_description: Secreted aspartic peptidases (SAPs) are a group of ten acidic hydrolases considered as key virulence factors. These enzymes supply the fungus with nutrient amino acids as well as are able to degrade the selected host's proteins involved in the immune defense. During infection, plays an important role in penetration into deeper tissues and interaction with host defense. Activates host systemic immunity and induces host inflammatory cytokine production in a proteolytic activity-independent way. Contributes to corneal pathogenicity. Moreover, acts toward human hemoglobin though limited proteolysis to generate a variety of antimicrobial hemocidins, enabling to compete with the other microorganisms of the same physiological niche using the microbicidal peptides generated from the host protein.
description: C. albicans secreted aspartic protease Sap6 is important for virulence during oral candidiasis since it degrades host tissues to release nutrients and essential transition metals. Zinc specifically increased C. albicans autoaggregation induced by Sap6; and Sap6 itself bound zinc ions. In silico analysis of Sap6 predicted four amyloidogenic regions that were synthesized as peptides (P1–P4). All peptides, as well as full length Sap6, demonstrated amyloid properties, and addition of zinc further increased amyloid formation.

alternative_names: Nuclear receptor subfamily 3 group C member 4
uniprot_description: Steroid hormone receptors are ligand-activated transcription factors that regulate eukaryotic gene expression and affect cellular proliferation and differentiation in target tissues. Transcription factor activity is modulated by bound coactivator and corepressor proteins. Transcription activation is down-regulated by NR0B2. Activated, but not phosphorylated, by HIPK3 and ZIPK/DAPK3. Isoform 3 and isoform 4 lack the C-terminal ligand-binding domain and may therefore constitutively activate the transcription of a specific set of genes independently of steroid hormones.
description: A conserved sequence from the central region of AR-NTD, KELCKAVSVSM, has an intrinsic property to form amyloid fibrils under mild oxidative conditions. The aggregation property of the KELCKAVSVSM peptide is heavily impacted by its neighboring sequences. When tagged with a SUMO protein, the KELCKAVSVSM peptide formed only dimers and no further high molecular weight species. However, when the length of the peptide was extended by over 200 amino acids to encompass the expanded polyQ stretch (Q45) of the AR, it potentiated the inherent property of the amplified polyQ stretch (Q45) to form fibrils. This shows a positive influence of the KELCKAVSVSM peptide on polyQ stretch fibrillization at the AR-NTD.

experimental_techniques: in vivo and in vitro aggregation assays
uniprot_description: Controls rRNA transcription by binding to the RNA polymerase (RNAP). Required for replication and persistence during infection of mice.
description: CarD is the first soluble cytosolic protein in Mtb which displays the tendency to form amyloid-like fibrils both in vitro as well as in vivo. The deletion of the fourteen N-terminal residues involved in domain-swapping hampers amyloid formation, thus, suggesting that domain-swapping is crucial in amyloidogenesis.

uniprot_description: Pseudokinase that plays a key role in TNF-induced necroptosis, a programmed cell death process. Activated following phosphorylation by RIPK3, leading to homotrimerization, localization to the plasma membrane and execution of programmed necrosis characterized by calcium influx and plasma membrane damage. Does not have protein kinase activity. Interaction with RIPK3 is species specific: human MLKL only interacts with human RIPK3 and not mouse RIPK3. Inhibited by necrosulfonamide, a specific inhibitor of necroptosis that targets Cys-86.
description: Upon necroptosis induction MLKL forms disulfide bond-dependent amyloid-like polymers that are distinct from RIPK1 and RIPK3 polymers. Recombinant MLKL N-terminal domain (NTD) forms fibers in vitro. NTD with all cysteines mutated fails to form polymers and is unable to induce necroptosis efficiently. Furthermore, compound necrosulfonamide (NSA) conjugates cysteine 86 of human MLKL to block MLKL polymer formation and subsequent cell death. Phosphorylation of MLKL by RIPK3 at T357 and S358 is required for MLKL polymer formation.

uniprot_description: PK1 is involved in step 5 of the subpathway that synthesizes pyruvate from D-glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate. The activity is regulated by glucose levels. Activated by fructose-1,6-bisphosphate.
description: Soluble Cdc19 proteins convert into amyloid-like aggregates. The shift of the equilibrium from the homo-tetramer towards the monomeric species plays a key role in inducing aggregation. The C-terminus LCR of Cdc19 in the homo-tetramer state is buried within the oligomeric structure, and monomerization leads to exposure of the hydrophobic LCR. In favorable growth conditions, this LCR is prevented from aggregating by phosphorylation or oligomerization, while upon glucose starvation it becomes exposed and allows reversible protein aggregation.

experimental_techniques: in vivo and in vitro aggregation assays
Congo red binding, absorbance and birefringence
description: YghJ is a secreted protein harboring an evolutionarily conserved zinc metalloprotease domain (aa 1081–1381) called M60-like. According to recent observations, YghJ acts as a mucin-degrading metalloprotease involved in triggering proinflammatory responses as well as in the colonization of the intestine by pathogenic strains of E. coli. The M60-like domain was shown to be the main functional region of YghJ responsible for mucin degradation.

uniprot_description: DNA-binding protein that specifically binds heat shock promoter elements (HSE) and activates transcription. Also required for growth at normal temperatures.
description: In yeast a disordered and low complexity region at the C-terminus of the Hsf1 transcription factor is predicted to act in molecular recognition, at the cost of aggregating spontaneously into ordered amyloid assemblies. A peptide corresponding to this region spontaneously self-assembles into CR- and ThT-positive β-sheet enriched amyloid fibrils in vitro. The biological relevance of this is not known.

experimental_techniques: in vivo RIPK3-based necroptosis complementation assay with PGRP-LC amyloidogenic segment
uniprot_description: Major activator of the imd/Relish pathway and is likely to encode a pattern recognition molecule for the humoral immune response. Required for Relish processing and nuclear translocation following proteolytic cleavage. Involved in the response to lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and peptidoglycan of Gram-negative bacteria. The different isoforms probably display different recognition capabilities to various microbial patterns.
description: In the Drosophila immune response, bacterial derived diaminopimelic acid-type peptidoglycan binds the receptors PGRP-LC and PGRP-LE, which through interaction with the adaptor protein Imd leads to activation of the NF-κB homolog Relish and robust antimicrobial peptide gene expression. PGRP-LC, PGRP-LE, and Imd each contain a motif with some resemblance to the RIP Homotypic Interaction Motif (RHIM), a domain found in mammalian RIPK proteins forming functional amyloids during necroptosis. Through their cryptic RHIM-like segments PGRP-LC and PGRP-LE form an amyloidal nucleus that enhances the formation of Imd fibrils.

experimental_techniques: in vivo RIPK3-based necroptosis complementation assay with PGRP-LE amyloidogenic segment
uniprot_description: Peptidoglycan-recognition protein that plays a key role in innate immnunity by binding to murein peptidoglycans (PGN) of Gram-negative bacteria and activating the imd/Relish pathway. Has no activity against on Gram-positive bacteria. Binds to diaminopimelic acid-type PGN (DAP-type PGN), an activator of the imd/Relish pathway. Functions synergistically with PGRP-LC in producing resistance to E.coli and B.megaterium infections, which have the DAP-type peptidoglycan. Acts both upstream and in parallel with PGRP-LC in the imd/Relish pathway, and is required for infection-dependent activation of melanization. Required for Relish processing and nuclear translocation following proteolytic cleavage. Its localization suggests a role in the recognition and subsequent activation of the signaling at the first point of contact with invading bacteria.
description: In the Drosophila immune response, bacterial derived diaminopimelic acid-type peptidoglycan binds the receptors PGRP-LC and PGRP-LE, which through interaction with the adaptor protein Imd leads to activation of the NF-κB homolog Relish and robust antimicrobial peptide gene expression. PGRP-LC, PGRP-LE, and Imd each contain a motif with some resemblance to the RIP Homotypic Interaction Motif (RHIM), a domain found in mammalian RIPK proteins forming functional amyloids during necroptosis. Through their cryptic RHIM-like segments PGRP-LC and PGRP-LE form an amyloidal nucleus that enhances the formation of Imd fibrils.

experimental_techniques: in vivo RIPK3-based necroptosis complementation assay with Imd amyloidogenic segment
description: In the Drosophila immune response, bacterial derived diaminopimelic acid-type peptidoglycan binds the receptors PGRP-LC and PGRP-LE, which through interaction with the adaptor protein Imd leads to activation of the NF-κB homolog Relish and robust antimicrobial peptide gene expression. PGRP-LC, PGRP-LE, and Imd each contain a motif with some resemblance to the RIP Homotypic Interaction Motif (RHIM), a domain found in mammalian RIPK proteins forming functional amyloids during necroptosis. Through their cryptic RHIM-like segments PGRP-LC and PGRP-LE form an amyloidal nucleus that enhances the formation of Imd fibrils.

uniprot_description: Amelogenin plays a role in the biomineralization of teeth. Seems to regulate the formation of crystallites during the secretory stage of tooth enamel development. Thought to play a major role in the structural organization and mineralization of developing enamel.
description: The Leucine-rich amelogenin (LRAP) is a natural splice-variant of amelogenin, a functional protein in vivo, containing conserved domains of amelogenin. LRAP aggregates hierarchically into assemblies with various sizes including scattered beads, beads-on-a-string and gel-like precipitations in the presence of both calcium and phosphate ions. LRAP adopts β-sheet secondary structure as the first step of self-assembly. The aggregation requires multiple β-strands coming together to form larger β-sheets, and amyloid-like structure suggests multiple layers of β-sheet formed. Beads are relatively stable intermediate self-assemblies with a core structure as cross-β-sheets. The further association of beads leads to rod-like structure. The rod-like structure could associate into strings and finally visible gel-like precipitation.

uniprot_description: This protein promotes the GTP-dependent binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the A-site of ribosomes during protein biosynthesis.
description: Elongation factor Tu (EF-Tu), which is one of the most abundant proteins in bacterial cells, participates in critical steps in protein biosynthesis and forms structural filaments in vitro. Furthermore, EF-Tu is involved in activities, such as adhesion, and interacts with extracellular matrix components or plasma proteins. EF-Tu from G. anatis presents amyloid characteristics, is present in biofilms and could be relevant for the pathogenesis of G. anatis.

experimental_techniques: in vivo and in vitro aggregation assays
description: The aggregates of lipase were characterized with a number of biophysical methods indicating that amyloid fibril formation by this protein is a very rapid, instantaneous process, with a significant number of fibrils present immediately after dilution, with an extremely rapid lag phase that remains undetectable on our time scale and with a rapidity that is independent of the time of incubation under the various conditions tested.
The OmpP2-like protein formed filaments in vitro. Antiserum against OmpP2-like reacted positively with biofilms, implying that the amyloid state has a role in the formation/maintenance of biofilms.

uniprot_description: Splits internally a 1,3-beta-glucan molecule and transfers the newly generated reducing end (the donor) to the non-reducing end of another 1,3-beta-glucan molecule (the acceptor) forming a 1,3-beta linkage, resulting in the elongation of 1,3-beta-glucan chains in the cell wall. Involved in cell wall biosynthesis and morphogenesis.
description: Gas1 is a member of the beta-1,3-glucanosyltransferase family required for cell wall assembly. Gas1 is also implicated in transcriptional silencing and is found at the nuclear periphery. Gas1 and the amyloidogenic Bgl2 are functionally related and participate in the incorporation of the GPI-anchored proteins into the cell wall.

uniprot_description: May be involved in cellular adaptations prior to stationary phase.
description: Ygp1 is a cell wall-related secretory glycoprotein. Its amyloid formation probably plays a role in the formation of an extracellular protective sheath.

uniprot_description: Serine-threonine kinase which transduces inflammatory and cell-death signals (programmed necrosis) following death receptors ligation, activation of pathogen recognition receptors (PRRs), and DNA damage. Upon activation of TNFR1 by the TNF-alpha family cytokines, TRADD and TRAF2 are recruited to the receptor. Phosphorylates DAB2IP at 'Ser-728' in a TNF-alpha-dependent manner, and thereby activates the MAP3K5-JNK apoptotic cascade. Ubiquitination by TRAF2 via 'Lys-63'-link chains acts as a critical enhancer of communication with downstream signal transducers in the mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway and the NF-kappa-B pathway, which in turn mediate downstream events including the activation of genes encoding inflammatory molecules. Polyubiquitinated protein binds to IKBKG/NEMO, the regulatory subunit of the IKK complex, a critical event for NF-kappa-B activation. Interaction with other cellular RHIM-containing adapters initiates gene activation and cell death. RIPK1 and RIPK3 association, in particular, forms a necrosis-inducing complex.
description: RIP1 and RIP3 kinases are central players in TNF-induced programmed necrosis. The RIP homotypic interaction motifs (RHIMs) of RIP1 and RIP3 mediate the assembly of heterodimeric filamentous structures. The fibrils exhibit classical characteristics of β-amyloids.

uniprot_description: Essential for necroptosis, a programmed cell death process in response to death-inducing TNF-alpha family members. Upon induction of necrosis, RIPK3 interacts with, and phosphorylates RIPK1 and MLKL to form a necrosis-inducing complex. RIPK3 binds to and enhances the activity of three metabolic enzymes: GLUL, GLUD1, and PYGL. These metabolic enzymes may eventually stimulate the tricarboxylic acid cycle and oxidative phosphorylation, which could result in enhanced ROS production.
description: RIP1 and RIP3 kinases are central players in TNF-induced programmed necrosis. The RIP homotypic interaction motifs (RHIMs) of RIP1 and RIP3 mediate the assembly of heterodimeric filamentous structures. The fibrils exhibit classical characteristics of β-amyloids.
